content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. To enhance border investigative resources on the Southwest border, funds are authorized for the United States Customs Service for salaries, expenses, and equipment. This includes $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. Funds are authorized for the United States Customs Service for salaries, expenses, and equipment to enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border. This includes $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. Additional funds are authorized for investigative resources against corruption, drug smuggling, and money-laundering organizations, as well as to reduce traffic waiting times at major land border ports of entry. Authorized funds for the Immigration and Naturalization Service for enhancing enforcement and inspection resources at major land border ports of entry on the Southwest and Northern borders of the United States include $113,604,000 for fiscal year 1999, $121,064,000 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for subsequent fiscal years. Additionally, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service in fiscal year 1999 for acquisition and deployment of narcotics-related expenses. In fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for the acquisition and deployment of narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funds for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, and pallet x-rays. In fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquiring and deploying narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funds for various equipment such as portable contraband detectors, contraband detection kits, ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, and rapid tire deflator systems. In fiscal year 1999, funds are allocated for acquiring and deploying various equipment for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System (TECS) terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, and weigh-in-motion sensors for ports with specific security needs. Additionally, funds are designated for counter-surveillance of Customs inspection activities outside ports, inbound commercial truck transponders, narcotics vapor and particle detectors for border crossings, and license plate reader software at ports targeting inbound vehicles. In fiscal year 1999, $15,090,000 is allocated for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, and Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System (TECS) terminals for border patrol checkpoints. The Attorney General has the same authority for amounts and equipment specified in subsection (b)(2) as the Commissioner of Customs for subsection (b)(1). $112,844,584 in fiscal year 1999 and $180,910,928 for peak hours and investigative resource enhancement in fiscal year 2000. In fiscal year 2000, $112,844,584 in fiscal year 1999 and $180,910,928 for peak hours and investigative resource enhancement, including increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders, and adding inspectors and canine enforcement officers at large cargo facilities to reduce waiting times. In fiscal year 2000, there was an increase in resources for processing and screening cargo at large cargo facilities, intensifying efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, enhancing investigative resources for anticorruption efforts, and covering costs incurred due to the increase. In fiscal year 2000, additional resources were allocated to the Office of Internal Affairs to enhance investigative resources for anticorruption efforts. Additionally, funds were designated for hiring personnel and increasing inspectors at the Southwest and Northern land borders to improve border security and investigative capabilities. The government allocated resources to enhance investigative efforts at the Northern land border, increase inspectors and canine officers at border patrol checkpoints, provide canine enforcement vehicles for inspection and enforcement at the Southwest border, and intensify efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering in major metropolitan areas. The government allocated resources to enhance investigative efforts at major metropolitan drug distribution centers, increase positions in the Office of the Inspector General for anticorruption efforts, and cover costs related to personnel increases.
